facts.text: Director Rob Reiner had to leave the set during the funny Billy Crystal scenes because his laughter was ruining the audio.
Andre the Giant (Fezzik) had such bad back pain that in the final scene, he wasn't riding a horse; he was on a mostly hidden ATV.
Cary Elwes (Westley) actually broke his toe during filming, which is why he walks carefully in some swamp scenes.
The fencing scene between Inigo and Westley took months of training and they performed the stunts themselves.
Mandy Patinkin (Inigo Montoya) said that the famous line about his father was the favorite line of his entire career.
The sounds of the Velociraptors communicating were actually recordings of tortoises mating.
The T-Rex animatronic would sometimes malfunction in the rain and turn on by itself, terrifying the crew.
Harrison Ford was offered the role of Dr. Alan Grant but turned it down.
The ripples in the water glass caused by the T-Rex footsteps were created by plucking a guitar string attached to the dashboard.
It was one of the first major films to use CGI dinosaurs, changing special effects history forever.
The original concept was set in the future with Ghostbusters as a standard public service like firefighters.
The line 'He slimed me' was an ad-lib by Bill Murray.
Shaving cream was used as the substitute for the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man's exploded remains.
The phone number in the original commercials was a working number that played a recorded message from Bill Murray and Dan Aykroyd.
The time machine was originally going to be a refrigerator, but they worried kids would climb into fridges.
Eric Stoltz was originally cast as Marty McFly and filmed for weeks before Michael J. Fox replaced him.
The script was rejected over 40 times by major studios before being greenlit.
In the original script, the time machine was powered by Coca-Cola.
The drawing of Rose wearing the necklace was actually drawn by director James Cameron.
The elderly couple hugging in bed as the ship sinks were based on the owners of Macy's department store, who died on the real Titanic.
It cost more to make the movie Titanic than it cost to build the actual ship in 1912.
The line 'I'm the king of the world!' was improvised by Leonardo DiCaprio.
The 'snow' falling in the poppy field scene was actually pure industrial asbestos.
Toto the dog earned $125 per week, which was more than the Munchkin actors were paid.
The Tin Man's oil was actually chocolate syrup.
Judy Garland had to wear a corset to make her look younger and flatter.
The show was originally titled 'Insomnia Cafe' before becoming 'Friends'.
Courteney Cox was originally asked to play Rachel, but she requested to play Monica instead.
The golden frame around the peephole was originally a mirror that a crew member broke.
Gunther (James Michael Tyler) was cast because he was the only extra who knew how to operate an espresso machine.
Bruce Willis appeared on the show for free after losing a bet to Matthew Perry.
Estelle Getty (Sophia) was actually a year younger than Bea Arthur (Dorothy), despite playing her mother.
It took 45 minutes of makeup to transform Estelle Getty into the 80-year-old Sophia.
Rue McClanahan (Blanche) had a clause in her contract allowing her to keep her costumes.
Despite all the cheesecake they ate, Bea Arthur actually hated cheesecake.
The executives originally hated the pilot, calling it 'weak' and 'about nothing'.
Kramer's sliding entrance was so popular that audiences had to be told to stop clapping so the scene could continue.
Jason Alexander based George Costanza on the show's co-creator, Larry David.
Elaine's father was meant to be a recurring character, but the actor terrified the cast so much they didn't bring him back.
The blue meth used in the show was actually blue rock candy crushed up.
Sony originally wanted Matthew Broderick to play Walter White.
Aaron Paul (Jesse Pinkman) was originally supposed to be killed off in season one.
The pizza toss onto the roof was done in one take.
John Krasinski (Jim) accidentally kissed Rainn Wilson (Dwight) on the cheek during an improv scene, but they cut it.
The computers on set were actually connected to the internet, so cast members would surf the web during background shots.
Phyllis Smith (Phyllis) was actually the casting associate for the show before the producers decided she should be in it.
Mario was originally a carpenter, not a plumber, and his name was 'Jumpman'.
The bushes and the clouds in the original Super Mario Bros. are the same sprite, just colored differently.
Mario is named after the landlord of Nintendo of America's first warehouse, Mario Segale.
Chain Chomps were inspired by a neighbor's dog that used to terrorize creator Shigeru Miyamoto.
The Creeper was created by accident when the developer tried to make a pig model but got the dimensions wrong.
Endermen speak English backwards and distorted.
The game was originally called 'Cave Game'.
It is the best-selling video game of all time.
The character design was inspired by a pizza with one slice missing.
The original name was 'Puck-Man', but it was changed to prevent vandalism of arcade cabinets.
Each ghost has its own distinct AI personality (one chases, one ambushes, one is random).
It was created by a Soviet software engineer named Alexey Pajitnov.
It was the first video game played in space.
Playing Tetris shortly after a traumatic event has been shown to reduce symptoms of PTSD.
He had a cameo in 39 of his 52 surviving major films.
He refused to let people enter the theater late for 'Psycho' to protect the plot twist.
He never won an Oscar for Best Director, despite five nominations.
He used chocolate syrup for blood in the black-and-white movie 'Psycho'.
He had an extreme fear of eggs (ovophobia).
He was rejected from film school at USC three times.
He is the godparent of Drew Barrymore and Gwyneth Paltrow.
He finished his college degree 34 years after dropping out, submitting 'Schindler's List' as his final project.
He took no salary for 'Schindler's List', calling any money from it 'blood money'.
The title 'Reservoir Dogs' came from a customer at the video store where he worked mispronouncing 'Au Revoir Les Enfants'.
He hand-writes his scripts before typing them.
The 'Red Apple' cigarette brand seen in his movies is a fictional brand he created.
He often uses the same 1964 Chevrolet Malibu in his films; it actually belongs to him.
He does not own a smartphone or have an email address.
He grew real corn for 'Interstellar' and then sold it for a profit.
He prefers to use practical effects and actually crashed a real Boeing 747 for the movie 'Tenet'.
A Middle Eastern country bordering Israel and Saudi Arabia.
Michael, the NBA legend who won six championships with the Bulls.
A popular sneaker brand featuring the 'Jumpman' logo.
A river that flows into the Dead Sea.
The closest planet to the Sun in our solar system.
Freddie, the legendary lead singer of Queen.
A silvery liquid metal often found in old thermometers.
The Roman messenger god known for his winged sandals.
The 16th President of the United States.
A luxury car brand owned by Ford.
The capital city of Nebraska.
A classic toy involving interlocking wooden logs.
The largest river in South America by discharge volume.
The world's largest online retailer founded by Jeff Bezos.
In Greek mythology, a tribe of warrior women.
A vast tropical rainforest covering much of Brazil.
The fourth letter of the Greek alphabet.
A major American airline based in Atlanta.
A landform created by deposition of sediment at a river mouth.
A term used in mathematics to represent change.
They were built as tombs for pharaohs, not as grain silos or alien beacons.
The Great Pyramid was the tallest man-made structure for over 3,800 years.
The workers who built them were paid laborers, not slaves, and were given beer rations.
They were originally covered in polished white limestone that shined in the sun.
The word literally means 'rebirth' in French.
It began in Florence, Italy, in the 14th century.
Leonardo da Vinci wrote his notes backwards so they could only be read with a mirror.
Michelangelo hated painting the Sistine Chapel and wrote a poem about how much his neck hurt.
Romans used crushed mouse brains as toothpaste.
They built a road network of over 50,000 miles, some of which are still used today.
Wealthy Romans would eat flamingo tongues as a delicacy.
The Colosseum could be flooded to stage mock sea battles.
Vikings never actually wore horned helmets; that was an invention of 19th-century opera costume designers.
They used a liquid called 'touchwood' made from tree fungus to start fires.
Viking men spent a lot of time on grooming and carried ear spoons and combs.
It was a gift from France to the United States.
The statue's exterior is made of copper, which turned green due to oxidation.
The 7 spikes on her crown represent the 7 continents and 7 seas.
Gustave Eiffel, who built the Eiffel Tower, helped design the internal skeleton.
It functioned as a lighthouse from 1886 to 1902.
Orville and Wilbur were bicycle mechanics before they were aviators.
Their first successful flight in 1903 lasted only 12 seconds.
They decided who would fly first by flipping a coin.
Their father believed it was impossible for men to fly and that flight was reserved for angels.
It started in 1848 when gold was found at Sutter's Mill in California.
The population of San Francisco grew from 1,000 to 25,000 in just two years.
Levi Strauss made his fortune selling durable denim pants to miners, not by mining gold.
Merchants often made more money than the miners themselves.
The computer that guided Apollo 11 had less processing power than a modern musical greeting card.
Neil Armstrong had to clear customs when he returned to Earth from the Moon.
The flag placed on the moon has likely been bleached white by the sun's radiation.
Buzz Aldrin was the first person to pee on the moon (into a special bag in his suit).
Your nose and ears never stop growing throughout your life.
The strongest muscle in the body based on weight is the jaw muscle (masseter).
Humans share about 60% of their DNA with bananas.
A human sneeze can travel about 100 miles per hour.
One day on Venus is longer than one year on Venus.
Space is completely silent because there is no atmosphere to carry sound.
Neutron stars can spin at a rate of 600 rotations per second.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth.
Footprints left on the Moon will stay there for millions of years because there is no wind.
Hot water freezes faster than cold water (known as the Mpemba effect).
If you could fold a piece of paper 42 times, it would reach the moon.
Light from the sun takes about 8 minutes and 20 seconds to reach Earth.
Atoms are 99.9999999% empty space.
The five rings represent the five inhabited continents of the world.
Gold medals are actually mostly made of silver.
In the ancient Olympics, athletes competed in the nude.
Live pigeon shooting was a one-time event in the 1900 Paris Games.
The game was invented by James Naismith using peach baskets as hoops.
Originally, the ball was brown; it was changed to orange for better visibility.
Dribbling wasn't part of the original game; players had to pass from where they caught the ball.
The NBA logo is a silhouette of Jerry West.
Golf is the only sport to have been played on the moon.
The chances of making two holes-in-one in a single round are about 1 in 67 million.
Until 1990, Augusta National (home of the Masters) did not allow African American members.
The word 'caddy' comes from the French word 'cadet', meaning student or cadet.
The World Cup is the most widely viewed sporting event in the world.
A standard soccer ball has 32 panels, representing the 32 countries in Europe (at the time of design).
The fastest red card in history was given 2 seconds after kickoff.
Brazil is the only country to have played in every single World Cup tournament.
The name comes from the Danish words 'leg godt', meaning 'play well'.
There are enough LEGO bricks to stack from Earth to the Moon ten times.
LEGO is the world's largest tire manufacturer (producing tiny rubber tires).
Six standard 2x4 LEGO bricks can be combined in over 915 million ways.
Barbie's full fictional name is Barbara Millicent Roberts.
She was created by Ruth Handler, who named the doll after her daughter, Barbara.
Barbie has had over 200 careers, including astronaut, surgeon, and president.
The first Barbie wore a black-and-white striped swimsuit.
It was originally invented as a wallpaper cleaner to remove coal soot.
The specific smell of Play-Doh is actually trademarked.
Over 3 billion cans of Play-Doh have been sold since its debut.
The game was originally designed to teach people about the dangers of capitalism.
More Monopoly money is printed every year than real US currency.
The longest game of Monopoly ever played lasted 70 straight days.
During WWII, Monopoly games sent to POWs contained hidden maps, compasses, and real money for escape.
He was originally going to be named Mortimer Mouse.
Walt Disney himself provided the original voice for Mickey.
Mickey was the first cartoon character to get a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
He only has four fingers because it was cheaper to animate.
There is a secret club called Club 33 located in New Orleans Square.
Walt Disney had a private apartment above the Fire Station on Main Street.
Feral cats are allowed to roam the park at night to keep the rodent population down.
The plants in Tomorrowland are meant to be edible.
The movie was originally titled 'King of the Jungle' until they realized lions don't live in jungles.
Pumbaa was the first Disney character to fart on screen.
The opening song is in Zulu and translates to 'Here comes a lion, father'.
It remains the highest-grossing traditionally animated film of all time.
Elsa was originally going to be the villain of the movie.
50 animators worked on just the scene where Elsa builds her ice palace.
The names Hans, Kristoff, Anna, and Sven are a tribute to Hans Christian Andersen.
They have three hearts: two for the gills and one for the rest of the body.
Their blood is blue because it is copper-based.
They have nine brains: one central brain and a mini-brain in each arm.
They can taste with their tentacles.
They are listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the 'most fearless animal'.
Their skin is so loose that they can twist around and bite an attacker holding them by the neck.
They are immune to most snake venoms, including cobras.
They move so slowly that algae grows on their fur.
Sloths can hold their breath longer than dolphins (up to 40 minutes).
They only poop once a week and lose up to a third of their body weight when they do.
Sharks have existed for longer than trees.
If a shark stops swimming, it will sink and suffocate (for most species).
Great White Sharks can detect one drop of blood in 25 gallons of water.
Sharks lose thousands of teeth in their lifetime and grow new ones constantly.
They are the only mammals that cannot jump.
Elephants can recognize themselves in a mirror, a sign of high intelligence.
Their trunks have over 40,000 muscles (humans have 600 in their entire body).
Baby elephants suck their trunks for comfort, just like human babies suck their thumbs.
It is the largest desert in the world (polar desert).
It holds about 70% of the world's fresh water.
There are no polar bears in Antarctica; they only live in the Arctic.
It is the only continent without reptiles or snakes.
It grows about 4 millimeters higher every year due to tectonic plates.
Over 300 climbers have died there, and many bodies remain as trail markers.
At the summit, there is only about one-third the amount of oxygen as at sea level.
There are no bridges that cross the entire width of the Amazon River.
It carries more water than the next seven largest rivers combined.
Before the Andes Mountains rose, the Amazon used to flow in the opposite direction (East to West).
Canada has more lakes than the rest of the world's lakes combined.
Russia is bigger than the surface area of Pluto.
France covers the most time zones of any country (12) due to its overseas territories.
Japan has over 6,800 islands.
J.K. Rowling wrote the initial ideas on a napkin on a train to London.
The character Dementors were based on Rowling's experience with depression.
It is the best-selling book series in history.
Arthur Weasley was originally going to die in the fifth book.
He invented over 1,700 words used in English today, including 'lonely' and 'eyeball'.
We don't know his exact birthday, but he died on April 23rd, which is celebrated as his birthday.
He left his wife his 'second-best bed' in his will.
His plays were performed by all-male casts; women were not allowed to act.
The book popularized terms like 'Big Brother', 'Doublethink', and 'Thought Police'.
Orwell originally wanted to title the book 'The Last Man in Europe'.
He wrote the book while suffering from tuberculosis.
It received mixed reviews upon release and was a commercial failure during Fitzgerald's lifetime.
It became a classic only after free copies were distributed to soldiers in WWII.
Fitzgerald considered titles like 'Trimalchio in West Egg' and 'The High-Bouncing Lover'.
Yoda was originally going to be played by a monkey wearing a mask.
The sound of a TIE fighter engine is a mix of an elephant call and a car driving on wet pavement.
Darth Vader is on screen for only 12 minutes in the original 'A New Hope'.
The phrase 'I have a bad feeling about this' is spoken in every movie.
J.R.R. Tolkien typed the entire trilogy with two fingers.
The Beatles wanted to make a LOTR movie starring themselves, but Tolkien refused.
Sean Connery turned down the role of Gandalf because he didn't understand the script.
Viggo Mortensen (Aragorn) actually broke two toes when kicking a helmet in frustration.
The green code rain is actually scanned recipes from a sushi cookbook.
Will Smith turned down the role of Neo to make 'Wild Wild West'.
Keanu Reeves shared his earnings with the special effects team and costume designers.
The TARDIS sound was created by running a key along a piano wire.
The show was originally intended to be educational, teaching kids about history and science.
The Daleks were inspired by Nazis.
The most expensive pizza in the world costs $12,000 and takes 72 hours to make.
The Hawaiian pizza was actually invented in Canada.
In 2013, NASA funded a project to 3D print pizza for astronauts.
Coffee beans are actually the pits of a fruit called a coffee cherry.
Beethoven was obsessed with coffee and counted out exactly 60 beans for every cup.
Finland consumes the most coffee per capita in the world.
The first webcam was invented at Cambridge University to check the status of a coffee pot.
True Champagne can only come from the Champagne region of France.
There are approximately 49 million bubbles in a standard bottle.
Marilyn Monroe once took a bath in 350 bottles of Champagne.
Tequila must be made from at least 51% blue agave plant.
Whiskey comes from the Gaelic 'uisge beatha', meaning 'water of life'.
Angel's Share is the amount of whiskey that evaporates from the barrel each year.
White chocolate isn't technically chocolate because it contains no cocoa solids.
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as currency.
It takes about 400 cocoa beans to make one pound of chocolate.
The smell of chocolate increases theta brain waves, which triggers relaxation.
A group of crows is called a 'Murder'.
A group of owls is called a 'Parliament'.
A group of flamingos is called a 'Flamboyance'.
A group of geese is a 'gaggle' on ground, but a 'skein' in flight.
A group of lions is called a 'Pride'.
A group of rhinos is called a 'Crash'.
A group of porcupines is called a 'Prickle'.
A group of giraffes is called a 'Tower'.
A group of lemurs is called a 'Conspiracy'.
A group of jellyfish is called a 'Smack'.
A group of stingrays is called a 'Fever'.
A group of sharks is called a 'Shiver'.
They officially broke up at Disney World.
None of the Beatles could read sheet music.
The song 'Yesterday' came to Paul McCartney in a dream.
Ringo Starr was the narrator for the first two seasons of 'Thomas the Tank Engine'.
She worked at Dunkin' Donuts but was fired for squirting jelly at a customer.
She has published several children's books.
She is the best-selling female recording artist of all time.
He tried to buy Marvel Comics in the 90s so he could play Spider-Man.
The 'Lean' in Smooth Criminal was achieved with patented special shoes.
His pets included a chimp named Bubbles and a python named Crusher.
She wrote her own monologue when she hosted Saturday Night Live.
She grew up on a Christmas tree farm.
She is the first woman to win the Album of the Year Grammy three times.
Brian May built his guitar, the 'Red Special', out of an old fireplace mantel with his dad.
The video for 'I Want to Break Free' was banned from MTV in the US.
Freddie Mercury had extra teeth in his upper jaw, which he believed gave him his vocal range.
Mozart wrote the overture to Don Giovanni the morning it was to be premiered, while hungover.
Bach once walked 200 miles to hear an organist play.
Tchaikovsky had a phobia that his head would fall off while conducting, so he held his chin with one hand.
Amelia Earhart was the first female aviator to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean.
Chuck Yeager was the first person to break the sound barrier.
The first hot air balloon passengers were a sheep, a duck, and a rooster.
The first text message ever sent said 'Merry Christmas'.
The first telephone book was only one page long.
The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson to himself.
Yuri Gagarin was the first human in space.
Laika the dog was the first living creature to orbit Earth.
Neil Armstrong was the first man to walk on the moon.
The first video uploaded was titled 'Me at the zoo'.
It was originally designed as a video dating site.
Gangnam Style was the first video to hit 1 billion views.
More video content is uploaded in 30 days than major US TV networks created in 30 years.
The word comes from Japanese 'e' (picture) and 'moji' (character).
The 'Face with Tears of Joy' ğŸ˜‚ was named Oxford Dictionary's Word of the Year in 2015.
The pizza emoji ğŸ• is one of the most popular food emojis worldwide.
World Emoji Day is July 17th because that is the date shown on the calendar emoji.
It was originally just an online bookstore.
Jeff Bezos almost named the company 'Cadabra', but people misheard it as 'Cadaver'.
In the early days, a bell would ring in the office every time a book was sold.
The name is a play on 'Googol', the mathematical term for a 1 followed by 100 zeros.
The first Google storage was built from LEGO bricks.
Google rents goats to mow the lawn at their headquarters.
The first Apple computer sold for $666.66.
Isaac Newton was featured on the first Apple logo.
If you smoke near an Apple computer, it voids the warranty.
Siri stands for 'Speech Interpretation and Recognition Interface'.
Bill Gates' first company was called Traf-O-Data, which tracked traffic flow.
The Windows startup sound was composed by Brian Eno on a Mac.
Microsoft saved Apple from bankruptcy in 1997 with a $150 million investment.
The Mona Lisa has no eyebrows; it was fashion in the Renaissance to shave them.
Van Gogh sold only one painting during his lifetime.
Picasso could draw before he could walk, and his first word was 'piz' (short for pencil).
The Scream exists in four different versions created by Edvard Munch.
Zeus was known for transforming into animals to visit Earth.
Medusa was once a beautiful priestess before being cursed by Athena.
The Titans were the parents of the Olympian gods.
Thor's hammer, Mjolnir, was made by dwarves.
Odin gave up one of his eyes in exchange for wisdom.
Vikings believed the Northern Lights were the reflections of Valkyrie armor.
The brain names itself.
You cannot tickle yourself because your cerebellum predicts the sensation.
Phantom Vibration Syndrome is when you think your phone is vibrating but it isn't.
Memories are deconstructed and reconstructed every time you think of them, making them less accurate over time.
